Coalition division on same-sex plebiscite Divisions emerge within the government over a new plan to lock in the results of a plebiscite on marriage equality with pre-election legislation. Courtesy ABC News24.
PT0M41S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Eric Abetz slams 'thought bubble' Coalition same-sex marriage plan Bill Shorten: Turnbull's $140m plebiscite risks a platform for abuse PM weighs decisive same-sex marriage plan Malcolm Turnbull has a problem on same-sex marriage that he needs to resolve sooner rather than later.
The nub of the problem is that he has been compelled to embrace a formula to deal with the issue that he did not support while Tony Abbott was in charge.
Senator Eric Abetz greets Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and Lucy Turnbull last week. Photo: Alex Ellinghausen
But the rub is that the ill-defined plebiscite approach he inherited from Abbott is not guaranteed to resolve the issue. This is because it was never articulated in any detail or subject to a proper process.
Advertisement Indeed, the suspicion of many marriage equality supporters was that it was conceived merely to put the issue off.
When the plebiscite proposal emerged back in August, Turnbull made it abundantly clear that he considered it a bad idea.
Malcolm Turnbull and Christopher Pyne listen to backbencher Warren Entsch introduce a private member's bill on marriage equality on August 17. Photo: Andrew Meares
Primarily, this was because it would ensure that marriage equality was a live issue up to and beyond the next election when there were huge challenges facing the nation.
But there was also the likely $160 million cost of a plebiscite and the fact that the High Court has already found Parliament has the capacity to change the definition of marriage to include same-sex couples.
And there was the uncertainty about how the plebiscite would be organised and how the result would be given legislative force.
Labor MP Clare O'Neil on Wednesday asked Malcolm Turnbull what would happen in the event of a successful same-sex marriage plebiscite. Photo: Andrew Meares
Would, for instance, legislation be introduced after the plebiscite to legalise marriage equality if a simple majority of voters supported it? More importantly, would Coalition MPs be bound to vote in favour of such legislation? After all, an overwhelming majority opposed a free vote on the issue in August.
Or would the legislation be introduced in advance of the election due next year, as suggested by Warren Entsch?
Far better, Turnbull and many other supporters of marriage equality believed before the change in prime ministers, to have a free vote of the Parliament now, even if it was defeated. Soon enough, it would come back and the change would be endorsed.
For weeks, Labor has been trying to nail Turnbull on the differences between his convictions and the policies and the approaches of the Abbott government. Whether they were talking climate change or budget cuts, they failed. It has been like wrestling with smoke.
That changed on Wednesday when Clare O'Neil referred to Turnbull's support for a plebiscite and asked: "Will the national result of the plebiscite be binding on Coalition members? Or will individual Coalition members be bound by the results in their individual seats? Or will the plebiscite not be binding on Coalition members at all?"
"That is a very good question and I thank you for it," he replied. "I think it is an absolutely reasonable request. The answer is that the consequence of a 'yes' vote in the plebiscite will be that same-sex marriage will be legal in Australia."
Now, the onus is on the Prime Minister to articulate how this will happen. The knee-jerk response of Eric Abetz is a pointer to the degree of difficulty.
